comment.author: 62379908@N00
comment._content: The bicycle looks like 1970.  We didn't have skinny tires, underslung handlebars, and derailers in my zip code in 1936.  Maybe in Australia or France, but not in the US.

comment.author: 52585175@N07
comment._content:
So that was his secret!!??  ;)
(All of the features on his Malvern Star/ BSA bicycle were in common use in 1936- tubular tyres, drop handlebars, derailleurs,etc. The van is definitely not from the '70s!!)

comment.author: 62379908@N00
comment._content: I guess I live in a backward country.  I never saw a bike like that until about 1970.  We had those old fat tired, single speed, coaster brake bikes.

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: Opperman was one of the great cyclists and had state of the art speed or racing bicycles to set his many world records
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.author: 46650209@N07
comment._content:
Racing bikes like these have existed since the 30s, my grandfather was an amateur racing cyclist in Italy in that period and rode a Bianchi very similar to this one.
He didn't pass PRO because his mother made him promise he wouldn't when she was in her deathbead dying from TBC.
He was called up for military service in 1937, fought the war  and eventually joined the Italian Police in 1945, retiring as a riot police NCO in 1980.
But he always had the passion for bicycles!
